level2.p: is an ebook reader with built in accessibility features. It allows you to open DAISY ebooks within Firefox, and have those books read out loud using either your screenreader or 's built in voicing features.

list.li: Browse to and select any ZIP or BKS2 file that contains a DAISY book, or select an OPF from an uncompressed DAISY book
If the book is password protected, will prompt you for the password

level3.h3: What kinds of books can read?
level3.p: is designed to read text only DAISY books, such as those from Bookshare, and DAISY books with text and audio. The current version does not play audio-only DAISY books; support for those will be including in an upcoming version.
If your question isn't answered by this manual, feel free to contact Bookshare's Customer Support.
You will need to have Flash Player installed and enabled. It's used to play back audio prompts and prerecorded audio. Text to speech will still work if Flash is unavailable.

uses your computer's "text to speech" (TTS) capabilities to read DAISY books. Windows XP (SP2), Windows Vista, and Mac OS X Leopard (10.5) all have built-in speech synthesis. On a Linux computer you will need to install espeak.

To test your TTS setup, open the "Voice Settings" dialog (Open the Tools menu, select , select Settings, and choose Voice Settings) and then press the "Test Voice" button. If you hear your computer speaking, then the TTS is working properly. Please contact us if you are unable to proceed.

level2.p: If you prefer to let your screenreader do the talking, press Alt Shift F3 (to jump to the content of the book). You will now be able to navigate the book as if it was a web page.

To have speak the book, press the play button (or press Alt Shift F3 to jump to the book's content, and press 'p' to start playback. It will begin reading from the top of the book. If you press 'p' or escape while the book is being read, will pause. Pressing 'p' again after that will resume from the same paragraph.
has three Narration Modes, which control what it will read to you. These can be chosen using keyboard shortcuts, or from the "Audio Settings" dialog. These are as follows:

level3.p: In this mode, will read Firefox menus, Firefox tab names, the settings dialogs, as well as everything needed to navigate and read a book. This mode is great for reading on computers without a separate screenreader installed, or if you prefer to pause your screenreader when you start up Firefox. You'll need to turn your screenreader back on if you wish to read web pages within Firefox, as does not yet provide that ability. To enable this mode, press Alt Shift F10.

In this mode, will narrate only the book and the navigation controls for the book. To hear anything else in Firefox, you will need to re-enable your screenreader. This mode allows you to use 's navigation key shortcuts, and to interact with the DAISY book at a more detailed level than your screenreader probably supports. To enable this mode, press Alt Shift F11.
can be completely silent if you prefer. This allows you to let your screenreader do the talking, or to read books without narration. To mute 's narration, press Alt Shift F12.

level2.p: There are three areas in the user interface: the table of contents (which is rendered as a sidebar), the navigation bar (which contains a control which allows you to skip to pages, and a notes menu), and the main book contents (which can be read by your screenreader like any regular web page, in Firefox.) It's important to understand that is an extension within Firefox itself, and as such there are many core Firefox features that are outside of the scope of this manual. DAISY books are loaded as individual tabs in Firefox; you can switch between tabs using the Ctrl tab key.

If you are using your screenreader to read the contents of the book, these are the only controls you need to learn. If you will be using 's built in voicing, then you will want to read the section describing navigation of a book after this one.

level3.p: The Table of Contents of the book or document is rendered as a tree in Firefox's sidebar. To move the focus to the Table of Contents, press Alt Shift F1. You will now be able to use the arrow keys to move through the contents; pressing enter on any heading will set the focus to the book's contents at that particular location.

The Navigation Bar is an overlay at the top of the book's contents. It contains three controls: paging, notes, and playback buttons. You can press Alt Shift F2 to jump to the navigation bar, and then tab between the elements. Managing notes, and changing pages will be described in more detail later in this guide.

level4.p: On the right of the navigation bar are visual playback controls. You can tab to these and press space to select them, but there are keyboard shortcuts for control of playback which you will find it more convenient to use. The following section will describe these in more depth.

level3.p: To jump to the book's contents, you can press Alt Shift F3. Many of 's navigation keys depend on you being focused on the book's contents directly.

level2.h2: Navigating A Book With Your Keyboard
level2.p: has keyboard shortcuts which give you control over the playback of a book.

level3.p: You can skip between elements (e.g. paragraphs) in the book using the next (ctrl /) and previous (ctrl ,) keys. If you use these keys while is reading, it will pause after reading the element that you navigated to. You can then press 'p' again to resume playback, or press next or previous again. You can also use the ctrl . key to reread the element at the current position.

When a list is read, will first announce "list", and then will speak each of the list items in turn. If the list is nested, the level is spoken before the list items are read. will announce "list complete".

sidebar.p: Sidebars are related content. Often you'll see them contain extra information like diagrams, related articles, or biographies.

level3.p: Content often continues "after" a sidebar.

When you encounter a table in during playback, automatically pauses. Within a table you can use the table navigation keystrokes (ctrl with arrow keys) to move around the table; if you hit one of the table edges, you will hear a system bell. The keyboard shortcut ctrl . will read the cell that you are currently on, if you'd like to hear it again. If you wish to have the table read to you cell by cell, just press play, and will resume reading. If you wish to skip the table completely, you can press escape.

level2.p: allows you to take notes as you are reading. Notes are displayed inside a box with an icon to differentiate them from the main text in the book. When is narrating the book to you, a note will be announced as "Note", and then read to you.

To create a note, either choose "Add Note" from the "My Notes" menu on the action bar, click the (+) icon on the action bar, or press ctrl i. You will be asked to enter a name for a note, and then the note itself. will automatically generate a name based on the note's location within the book, but you don't need to use its suggestion.

Once a note is created, it will appear in three places: the book text, the table of contents, and the "My Notes" menu. Choosing a note from the "My Notes" menu or the table of contents will navigate directly to the note within the book. If you want to delete or change a note, you can do so by choosing the "Manage Notes" option from the "My Notes" menu.
You can quickly skip between notes in a book using the keyboard; ctrl alt [ and ctrl alt ] will step between the previous and next notes.

You probably noticed that this user guide has page numbers. As you navigate the book, the action bar will change to show you which page you are currently on. To navigate back and forwards by page, use the keyboard shortcuts alt ctrl ; and alt ctrl '. Alternatively, you can jump to the navigation bar (alt shift F2), and tab once to hear the current page. If you type a new page number and press enter, will jump to the new page.
has three settings dialogs, all of which can be invoked from the Tools / / Settings menu.

level3.p: This allows you to choose the speech rate and length of pause.
Speech Rate changes the speed of 's narration. You can also control the speech rate via keyboard shortcuts, using alt pageup to increase and alt pagedown to decrease the speed of the voice.
Use the Preview button to hear how the new settings sound. If you're satisfied, press Save. If you want to revert to how they were, press Cancel to close the dialog without saving.

currently will use the default voice on your computer. In Windows, this can be changed from the SAPI settings screen in the control panel. In OSX, changing the VoiceOver settings will change the voice used. Under Linux, you cannot currently change ESpeak's default voice. Future versions of will offer more control of which voice is used on all platforms.
This allows you to control 's audio prompts.
Voicing Mode allows you to choose which Narration Mode to use.
When Play Sound When Launches is enabled, will play an audio tone when it first launches.
When Play Sound When Moving Between Navigation Areas is enabled, will play different audio tones when you toggle between the Table of Contents, Navigation Bar, and Book.
These settings allow you to control aspects of how displays books.

When Show Images When Displaying Books is enabled, images will be loaded as you navigate through the book. If necessary, you can speed up the loading and overall navigation of books by turning this feature off.

Use Prerecorded Narration When Available allows you to use human narration if supplied with the DAISY book. If you turn this option off, will use your Narration Mode settings to determine whether or not to use text to speech.

Enable Quirks Mode is a setting for content producers. If you turn this option off, will only load strictly correct DAISY content. In future versions, this setting will be expanded to do more validation; currently, it toggles strict validation of certain namespaces.
